instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3662: What is 820-3662? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.5V_S5: What is 5V_S5? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S5” which is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 state. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3S5_EN: What is PP3V3S5_EN? PP3V3S5_EN is a typo ofP3V3S5_EN_L which is a signal that enables the power chip responsible for creating PP3V3_S5..
definitions.3V3S5_EN: What is 3V3S5_EN? P3V3S5_EN is a signal that enables the power chip responsible for creating PP3V3_S5.
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS, <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Liquid damaged board.

Looks to have been cleaned with IPA but still shows liquid signs

Crusty around <TRANSISTOR>Q8060</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q8052</TRANSISTOR> replaced
Also <CAPACITOR>C7317</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7318</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7319</CAPACITOR> replaced <CAPACITOR>C7317</CAPACITOR> was particularly fucked.
<CHIP>U7310</CHIP> replaced.

PPBUS = 3.9V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.9V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> on scope hits 3V3 and slopes down. Cycles.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS, <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Do you get light on MagSafe?
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> stable?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS, <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 16048"]Do you get light on MagSafe?
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> stable?
[/QUOTE]

Yes stable 3V42, yes green / orange
PPBUS 3.9V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS, <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Changed 6259
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is back
<SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> is back stable 5V.

<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is 0V on scope
Short on 3V3 someplace

threads.message: Did you measure resistance with no power applyed and waiting for a moment for the circuit to discharge???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS, <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="aprendiz, post: 16077"]Did you measure resistance with no power applyed and waiting for a moment for the circuit to discharge???[/QUOTE]

Yep. It's 4.2Ohms so I guess I'll just wack some Amps through it and see what gets hot.....

However this is not making sense as earlier <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> was cycling.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS, <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Ah. My bottom lip just detected a short through <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>
Replacing <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> did not work!
This new <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> is getting hot too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS, <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V_S5</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS, <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yep just found that one.. As well as <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS, <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Remove <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> and see if the short is under the chip. <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> is going to have a low resistance to ground because it is a low voltage line powering a high powered large BGA.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS, <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="larossmann, post: 16131"]Remove <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> and see if the short is under the chip. <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> is going to have a low resistance to ground because it is a low voltage line powering a high powered large BGA. [/QUOTE]

No short under <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> and PPVRTC still shorted without <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> on the board. Caps on PPVRTC are all fine. <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> also shorted. I had already restored PPBUS and <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL>.

This is a bit long now.
Your help [I]is[/I] much appreciated... But fuck this board man.

Many thanks all.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS, <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: what I do with rabbit holes is just start removing everything that could be pulling down the voltage or shorting to ground, if that doesnt work start removing bits that lead to other lines, one job of mine today was like that, one of the 1v s0 rails was shorted to ground, pretty much everything removed and still there, only thing left was the cpu, customer called, is now in the bin

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS, <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I removed the caps on PPVRTC and the <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> and it was still short on PPVRTC so we'll call it an expensive Frisbee.
